## Question 1: Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium
### part 1.1
We say the population size of the first generation is 10000, and probability of alleles "A" and "a" are equally 0.5. Then we have the allele pairs as follows, and it has approximately reached Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium. 

```{r}
### part 1.1
sim1<-function(N,p){
  ## N, population size
  ## p, probability of allele A
  pop<-NULL
  AA<-0;Aa=0;aa=0
  for(i in 1:N){
    a<-sample(c("A","a"),1,prob=c(p,1-p))
    b<-sample(c("A","a"),1,prob=c(p,1-p))
    if(setequal(c(a,b),c("A","A"))) AA=AA+1
    if(setequal(c(a,b),c("A","a"))) Aa=Aa+1
    if(setequal(c(a,b),c("a","a"))) aa=aa+1
    pop<-rbind(pop,c(a,b))
  }
  print(paste("Proportion of AA is:",AA/N))
  print(paste("Proportion of Aa is:",Aa/N))
  print(paste("Proportion of aa is:",aa/N))
  return (pop)}

par<-sim1(10000,0.5)
```

If we ignore the gender issue, and sample from the population into 5000 pairs as parents, and every pair is going to have one child. Then Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium has approximately been reached as well. 

```{r}
sim2<-function(par,p){
  chi<-NULL ## child allele matrix
  AA<-0;Aa=0;aa=0
  N<-nrow(par)  ## number of parent population
  pair_ind<-1:N ## index of parents
  for(i in 1:(N/2)){
    fam_ind<-sample(pair_ind,2,replace=F) ## index of family/parents 
    pair_ind<-pair_ind[-(which(pair_ind==fam_ind[1] | pair_ind==fam_ind[2]))]
    a<-sample(par[fam_ind[1],],1,p) ## allele from parent 1
    b<-sample(par[fam_ind[2],],1,p) ## allele from parent 2
    if(setequal(c(a,b),c("A","A"))) AA=AA+1
    if(setequal(c(a,b),c("A","a"))) Aa=Aa+1
    if(setequal(c(a,b),c("a","a"))) aa=aa+1
    chi<-rbind(chi,c(a,b))
  }
  print(paste("Proportion of AA is:",AA*2/N))
  print(paste("Proportion of Aa is:",Aa*2/N))
  print(paste("Proportion of aa is:",aa*2/N))
  return (chi)
}

chi<-sim2(par,0.5)
```

Therefore, according to recursion rule, with random mating, a population in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium will never deviate from it.

### part 1.2
Since the p-value is less than 0.01, thus the population has not significantly reached Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium.

```{r}
### part 1.2
blod<-c(357,485,158)
res<-chisq.test(blod,p=c(0.25,0.5,0.25))
res
```

### part 2.1
The protein products of the CDS is caled "RecQ type DNA helicase".

### part 2.2
The first four amino acids are Methionine/M, Valine/V, Valine/V, Alanine/A.

### part 2.5
The nucleotide number corresponding to the protein sequence is 5661-409*3=4434, since there are 409 stop codons. The genomic sequence lie on chromosome I.

```{r}
st<-c("TAA","TAG","TGA")
len<-nchar(nuc_cds)
ind<-NULL
for(i in 1:(len-2)){
  sample<-substr(nuc_cds,i,i+2)
  if(sample %in% st) ind<-c(ind,i)
}
print(paste("There are",length(ind),"stop codons in the nucleotide sequence."))

#ce<-NULL
#for(i in 1:(length(ind)-1))  ce<-c(ce,ind[i+1]-ind[i])
#sum(ce)
  
```

## Question 3: Exploring a genomic sequence

### part 3.1
C. elegans is a transparent 1-mm nematode that lives in temperate soil environments. In 1974, Sydney Brenner began research into the molecular and developmental biology of C. elegans, since which C. elegans has been extensively used as a model organism. It was the first multicellular organism with whole genome sequenced, and is the only organism to have its connectome completed until 2019.


### part 3.2

<center>

![BLAST](Lab1_3.2.png)

</center>


```{r}
gdna<-""
```

### part 3.3
Genomic query sequence corresponds the interval 6529-8028 of the subject sequence, and they progress in the same direction. And the reverse complement sequence progress in the opposite direction to the subject sequence, and corresponds the interval 8028-6529 of it.


<center>

![BLAST](Lab1_3.3.png)

</center>

### part 3.4
The query sequence is found on chromosome V 6529-8028.

### part 3.6
"ife-3", aka. Initiation Factor 4E (eIF4E) family, exhibits RNA 7-methylguanosine cap binding activity, involved in embryo development, expressed in germ line. It is an ortholog of human EIF4E (eukaryotic translation initiation factor 4E) and EIF4E1B (eukaryotic translation initiation factor 4E family member 1B). Its genomic position is V:6584-7828.
